org.dellroad.stuff.vaadin22.fieldbuilder

Class GeneratedCustomField<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.vaadin.flow.component.Component
      • com.vaadin.flow.component.AbstractField<CustomField<T>,T>
        • com.vaadin.flow.component.customfield.CustomField<T>
          • org.dellroad.stuff.vaadin22.fieldbuilder.GeneratedCustomField<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - field value type
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    AttachNotifier, BlurNotifier<CustomField>, DetachNotifier, Focusable<CustomField>, FocusNotifier<CustomField>, HasElement, HasEnabled, HasHelper, HasSize, HasValidation, HasValue<AbstractField.ComponentValueChangeEvent<CustomField<T>,T>,T>, HasValueAndElement<AbstractField.ComponentValueChangeEvent<CustomField<T>,T>,T>, Serializable, HasInternalValidator<AbstractField.ComponentValueChangeEvent<CustomField<T>,T>,T>

    public class GeneratedCustomField<T>
extends CustomField<T>
implements HasInternalValidator<AbstractField.ComponentValueChangeEvent<CustomField<T>,T>,T>
    Support superclass that mostly automates the creation of CustomFields for editing any model type having FieldBuilder annotations, using automatically generated sub-fields.

    This field uses a FieldBuilder to generate sub-fields for the annotated properties of a user-supplied model class. As with any other CustomField, this allows editing instances of the model class as a single property within some containing class. The containing class could then specify this class as the editor for that property with a @FieldBuilder.CustomField annotation.

    Each GeneratedCustomField contains an internal Binder to which its sub-fields are bound. Subclasses can customize the Binder, e.g., to add additional cross-field validation, etc. Subclasses can also customize the layout of the sub-fields via layoutComponents().

    This class also implements HasInternalValidator, which facilitates for recursive validation when this field is used within an outer FieldBuilder; see FieldBuilder for details.

    Put another way, this class provides the glue that allows FieldBuilder to work recursively, while also promoting modularity.

    Example

    Suppose model class Contract has a "term" property of type DateInterval which has a start and end date. We want to use FieldBuilder annotations to define the editor fields for the properties of Contract, including "term", but for that to work we will need to specify a custom field to handle the "term" property.

    Ideally, we want this custom field not only to contain the logic for laying out the start and end date components, but also to contain the logic for validating their proper ordering, as that is a concern for DateInterval and not Contract. This class provides a way to do that.

    For example: 

     // This is complex type that we wish to edit with a single CustomField
 public class DateInterval {

     @FieldBuilder.DatePicker(label = "Start date")
     public LocalDate getStartDate() { ... }
     public void setStartDate(LocalDate date) { ... }

     @FieldBuilder.DatePicker(label = "End date")
     public LocalDate getEndDate() { ... }
     public void setEndDate(LocalDate date) { ... }
 }

 // This is the corresponding custom field for editing a DateInterval
 public class DateIntervalField extends GeneratedCustomField<DateInterval> {

     public DateIntervalField() {
         super(DateInterval.class);
     }

     // Ensure end date is after start date
     @Override
     protected Binder<DateInterval> createBinder() {
         return super.createBinder().withValidator(i -> i.getStartDate().isBefore(i.getEndDate()) ?
             ValidationResult.ok() : ValidationResult.error("Dates out-of-order"));
     }

     // Customize how we want to layout the subfields
     @Override
     protected void layoutComponents() {

         // Get sub-fields
         final FieldBuilder.BoundField startDateField = this.fieldBuilder.getBoundFields().get("startDate");
         final FieldBuilder.BoundField endDateField = this.fieldBuilder.getBoundFields().get("endDate");

         // Layout sub-fields
         final HorizontalLayout layout = new HorizontalLayout();
         layout.add(startDateField.getComponent());
         layout.add(new Text("-"));
         layout.add(endDateField.getComponent());
         this.add(layout);
     }
 }

 // Now FieldBuilder works recursively for this multi-level class
 public class Contract {

     @FieldBuilder.CheckBox(label = "Approved?")
     public boolean isApproved() { ... }
     public void setApproved(boolean approved) { ... }

     @FieldBuilder.CustomField(label = "Term", implementation = DateIntervalField.class)
     public DateInterval getTerm() { ... }
     public void setTerm(DateInterval term) { ... }
 }

    Details

    Subclasses are responsible for laying out the sub-fields and any additional Binder configuration.

    The field's value type must have a public zero-arg constructor.

    • Method Detail

      • createFieldBuilder

        protected AbstractFieldBuilder<?,T> createFieldBuilder()
        Create a new AbstractFieldBuilder for the given type.

        The implementation in GeneratedCustomField returns a new FieldBuilder each time.

        Returns:
        field builder

      • createBinder

        protected Binder<T> createBinder()
        Create a new Binder for the given type.

        The implementation in GeneratedCustomField delegates to Binder(Class). Subclasses can override this method to substitute BeanValidationBinder, add additional validators, etc.

        Returns:
        field builder

      • layoutComponents

        protected void layoutComponents()
        Layout components required for this field.

        The implementation in GeneratedCustomField iterates the bound fields in fieldBuilder into a new HorizontalLayout which is then added to this instance. Subclasses will typically override this method to add decoration and/or layout differently.

      • createNewBean

        protected T createNewBean()
        Create a new/empty instance of the bean model class.

        This value is used to initialize fields to their default values.

        The implementation in GeneratedCustomField attempts to invoke a default constructor for the bean class.

        Returns:
        new empty bean

      • getInternalValidator

        public Validator<T> getInternalValidator()
        Description copied from interface: HasInternalValidator
        Provide Validator's to be used when this field is bound into a Binder.

        Returns:

      • buildValidationResult

        protected ValidationResult buildValidationResult(BinderValidationStatus<T> status)
        Build a ValidationResult from the given BinderValidationStatuss.

        The implementation in GeneratedCustomField simply returns an "Invalid" result if the given status contains any errors, otherwise ValidationResult.ok().

        Parameters:
        status - validation status from internal binder
        Returns:
        ValidationResult encapsulating status to be forwarded to the outer binder
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if status is null
